citeinfo.title: Digital map of water-level changes in the High Plains aquifer in parts of Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska, New Mexico, Oklahoma, South Dakota, Texas, and Wyoming, predevelopment (about 1950) to 2013
Water-Level Changes and Change in Water in Storage in the High Plains Aquifer, Predevelopment to 2013 and 2011-13

serinfo.sername: U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Report

descript.abstract: The High Plains aquifer extends from south of 32 degrees to almost 44 degrees north latitude and from 96 degrees 30 minutes to 104 degrees west longitude. The aquifer underlies about 175,000 square miles in parts of Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska, New Mexico, Oklahoma, South Dakota, Texas, and Wyoming. This dataset consists of a raster of water-level changes for the High Plains aquifer, predevelopment (about 1950) to 2013. This digital dataset was created using water-level measurements from 3,349 wells measured in both the predevelopment period (about 1950) and in 2013 and using other published information on water-level change in areas with few water-level measurements. The map was reviewed for consistency with the relevant data at a scale of 1:1,000,000.
descript.purpose: This dataset was created to document water-level changes in the High Plains aquifer from predevelopment (about 1950) to 2013.
descript.supplinf: This raster dataset is associated with the U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Report (SIR 2014-5218, McGuire, 2014), which describes the methods used to generate this raster dataset.

idinfo.useconst: This dataset was generated and reviewed at a scale of 1:1,000,000. The raster cell size is 500 meters by 500 meters, or about 62 acres and should not be used for more detailed analysis.
idinfo.datacred: The water-level data used to map water-level changes was provided by the following Federal, State, and local entities: Colorado--Division of Water Resources (also known as the Office of the State Engineer); Kansas--Department of Agriculture, Division of Water Resources and the Kansas Geological Survey; Nebraska--Central Nebraska Public Power and Irrigation District, Natural Resources Districts, and University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Conservation and Survey Division; New Mexico--Office of the State Engineer; Oklahoma--Water Resources Board; South Dakota--Department of Environment and Natural Resources; Texas--Groundwater Conservation Districts and the Water Development Board; Wyoming--State Engineers Office; and Federal--Bureau of Reclamation, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, and U.S. Geological Survey.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.1.1.3143

attracc.attraccr: The water-level-change data used as the basis for this dataset were computed primarily from water levels measured in wells during both the predevelopment period and in 2013 and from other published data.

qattracc.attracce: The precision of the water-level measurements is estimated to be 0.01 feet (ft), if there is not oil in the well. The accuracy of the water-level measurements can be affected by many factors; if there is oil on the surface of the water, the error in the water-level measurement could be as much as 5 ft, depending on the depth of the oil. The accuracy of the water-level change value for a given cell is dependent on the proximity of cell to measured wells. The average, median, and maximum distance between wells, which were measured in predevelopment and in 2013, is 3.2 miles, 2.7 miles, and 20.1 miles, respectively. In the area of water-level changes from a decline of 5 ft to a rise of 5 ft, the cell's water-level change value was set to zero because of uncertainty in the interpolation of water-level changes less than 5 ft, especially in areas with few measured wells.

dataqual.complete: Dataset is complete for the High Plains area. Data gaps within the High Plains boundary indicate areas where the aquifer is not present.

horizpa.horizpar: The accuracy of the water-level change value for a given cell is dependent on the proximity of cell to measured wells. The average, median, and maximum distance between wells, which were measured in predevelopment and in 2013, is 3.2 miles, 2.7 miles, and 20.1 miles, respectively. The interpolation process uses the water-level change value from measured wells and other supporting data. For cells collocated with measured well(s), the interpolation process results in cell values that are generally similar to, but commonly not equal to, the calculated values for the measured well(s).

procstep.srcused: University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Conservation and Survey Division, 2013

procstep.procdesc: The Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 command POLYGRID was used to generate a raster titled g02_aqisle with the cells equal to 1 in the internal areas where the aquifer is not present (Qi, 2010)This grid is used later to modify the water-level-change raster's cell value to null in the internal areas where the aquifer is not present.

The Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 command POLYGRID was used to generate a raster titled gnosatpoly09 of areas with little or no saturated thickness (Gutentag and others, 1984; Cederstrand and Becker, 1999a; Qi, 2010).

The Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 command ARCPOINT was used to generate a point file of the aquifer boundary titled aq_only_pt with attribute field beginval equal to 0 (Qi, 2010) for each point. This was done to control interpolated water-level change at the aquifer boundary.

The Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 command POLYGRID was used to generate a raster, titled h_ldpd13_g, of an area in the central Platte River valley in Nebraska, where predevelopment water levels are not available, but water-level rises of at least 10 ft were reported (Luckey and others, 1981; Gutentag and others, 1984). The raster value was set to 1 in the central Platte River valley area and 0 elsewhere.

The primary point dataset, hp_pd13pts, was prepared consisting of wells with predevelopment and a measured or, for New Mexico and Wyoming, estimated 2013 water levels (Kansas Geological Survey, 2014; Texas Water Development Board, 2014; U.S. Geological Survey, 2014). The data item deltapd_13 was calculated for each of these well by subtracting the predevelopment water-level measurement from the measured or estimated 2013 water level.

An supplemental point dataset was prepared consisting of wells without a predevelopment water level, but with a post-development water level, that is, wells having a water-level measurement prior to June 15, 1978 (U.S. Geological Survey, 2014), and a 2013 water levels (Kansas Geological Survey, 2014; Texas Water Development Board, 2014; U.S. Geological Survey, 2014). The data item deltapd_13est was calculated for each of these well by subtracting the water-level measurement prior to June 15, 1978 from the 2013 water level.

An additional supplemental point dataset was prepared consisting of wells without a predevelopment water level or a post-development water level, that is, a water-level measurement prior to June 15, 1978 (U.S. Geological Survey, 2014), but with a 1980 water level (Gutentag and others, 1984), and a 2013 water level (Kansas Geological Survey, 2014; Texas Water Development Board, 2014; U.S. Geological Survey, 2014). The data item deltapd_13est was calculated for each well using estimated water-level change, predevelopment to 1980 from Luckey and others (1981) map and water-level change, 1980 to 2013.

The Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 TOPOGRID command was used to generate an initial grid of water-level change from predevelopment to 2013 using as inputs the calculated value deltapd_13 for each well measured in predevelopment and 2013, the aquifer boundary (Qi, 2010), and, to guide water-level contours in areas with few wells, contours of water-level change, predevelopment to 2011 (McGuire, 2013).
procstep.srcused: University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Conservation and Survey Division, 2014

procstep.procdesc: The raster output from the initial run of Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 TOPOGRID was contoured using the Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 CONTOUR command. The contour intervals were less than -150 ft, -150 to -100 ft, -100 to -50 ft, -50 to -25 ft, -25 to -10 ft, -10 to -5 ft, -5 to +5 ft, 5 to 10 ft, 10 to 25 ft, and greater than 50 ft.

A map of the contours of water-level change, predevelopment to 2013, was prepared with the primary and supplemental point datasets presented for a manual review and revision of the contours particularly in areas where few wells had the applicable water-level measurements. The modified contours were converted to polygons, using the Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 BUILD command, each polygon was populated with the contour range, and the polygons were converted into two rasters using the Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 POLYGRID command. One raster, r1_pd13max, was populated with the lowest (for polygons of declines) or highest (for polygons of rises) value of the polygon range, that is, -149.99 for the polygon of declines less than or equal to -100 ft and greater than -150 ft, and 49.99 for the polygons of rises greater than or equal to 25 ft and less than 50 ft. The second raster, r2_pd13min, was populated with the highest (for polygons of declines) or lowest (for polygons of rises) value of the polygon range, that is -100.01 for the polygon of declines less than or equal to -100 ft and greater than -150 ft, and 25.01 ft for the polygons of rises greater than or equal to 25 ft and less than 50 ft.

The Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 command POLYGRID was used to create a raster of the areas of water-level changes between a rise of 5 ft and a decline of 5 ft. The value of the raster, titled h_nscpd13_g, is 1 in these areas and 0 elsewhere.

The Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 TOPOGRID command was used to generate a revised raster of water-level change from predevelopment to 2013 using as inputs the calculated value deltapd_13 for each well measured in predevelopment and 2013 (Kansas Geological Survey, 2014; Texas Water Development Board, 2014; U.S. Geological Survey, 2014), the aquifer boundary (Qi, 2010), and, to guide water-level contours in areas with few wells, the manually modified contours of water-level change, predevelopment to 2013. TOPOGRID was run with (1) the boundary equal to the aquifer outer boundary; (2) the point file of the aquifer boundary, aq_only_pt, using attribute field beginval; (3) the point file hp_pd13pts, attribute field deltapd_13; (4) the contour file v2WLCPD13b, attribute field tgcontour; (5) drainage enforcement off; (6) tolerances set to 0 for accuracy and density of the elevation points, 1 for horizontal standard error, and 0 for vertical standard error; and (7) 30 iterations. The output TOPOGRID raster was titled h_ga01a_pd13.
procstep.srcused: University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Conservation and Survey Division, 2013

procstep.procdesc: The Esri Arc/Info Version 10.0 command ZONALMEAN was applied to the final raster of water-level changes to calculate the water-level change statistics for the entire aquifer and for each State, in ft.
The raster with areas of no substantial change set to zero, which was titled h_ga01d_pd13, was renamed hp_wlcpd13g.
Converted the raster hp_wlcpd13g to ASCII using Raster-to-ASCII tool in Esri ArcGIS 10.1SP1 for Desktop. The ASCII output was named hp_wlcpd13a.txt

attr.attrdef: Water-level changes, in ft, predevelopment (about 1950) to 2013

overview.eaover: This floating-point raster dataset represent water-level change in the High Plains aquifer from predevelopment to 2013, in ft. The maximum and minimum value of the raster is -255.96 ft to 82.53 ft. The measured values for water-level changes, predevelopment to 2013, ranged from a decline of 256 ft for a well in Texas to a rise of 85 ft for a well in Nebraska. The interpolation process used to generate the rasters referred to in this report results in cell values, for cells collocated with a measured well, that are generally similar to, but commonly not exactly equal to, the corresponding values based on those water-level measurements. The cell values represent the value for an area 500 meters by 500 meters and the measured values are point values within the area represented by the cell.
overview.eadetcit: This raster dataset is shown in figure 1 in the report (SIR 2014-5218, McGuire, 2014) titled "Water-Level Changes and Change in Water in Storage in the High Plains Aquifer, Predevelopment to 2013 and 2011-13."

stdorder.fees: None. This dataset is provided by USGS as a public service.
